conclusion: Consider principles of refraction and total internal reflection.
Light beam is incident from air to transparent medium at point A.
Refractive index of air is \( n_1 = 1 \) and medium is \( n_2 > 1 \).
According to Snell's Law: \( n_1 \sin(i) = n_2 \sin(r) \).
Light travels through medium and reaches opposite side of sphere.
Total internal reflection occurs when angle of incidence is greater than or equal to critical angle \( \theta_c \).
For total internal reflection, angle of incidence inside medium must be greater than or equal to \( \theta_c \).
Depends on refracted angle \( r \) and geometry of sphere.
Light path is symmetric with respect to center \( O \) of sphere.
Angle of incidence at inner surface depends on refracted angle \( r \) and radius of sphere.
If incident angle \( i \) is large enough, refracted angle \( r \) results in angle of incidence greater than or equal to \( \theta_c \).
Total internal reflection occurs when incident angle \( i \) is sufficiently large.
Final Answer: Yes, if incident angle \( i \) is large enough, light will be totally internally reflected.
